items.title: An error occurred while retrieving auth cookies from https://mycompany.sharepoint.com/sites/documentssite//_vti_bin/idcrl.svc
items.body:
Hello there,

### Context of the issue
I'm working with the version **2.1.7.post1** (according to pip freeze), no MFA required to log in sharepoint.
I'm currently trying to get an excel file from the company's sharepoint, with the following script (built from README of the project) :
```python
from office365.runtime.auth.authentication_context import AuthenticationContext
from office365.sharepoint.client_context import ClientContext
from office365.sharepoint.file import File

url = 'https://mycompany.sharepoint.com/sites/documentssite/'

ctx_auth = AuthenticationContext(url)
if ctx_auth.acquire_token_for_user(username, password):
    ctx = ClientContext(url, ctx_auth)
    web = ctx.web
    ctx.load(web)
    ctx.execute_query()
    print("Web title: {0}".format(web.properties['Title']))
```
Running this script provides the following output :
```An error occurred while retrieving auth cookies from https://mycompany.sharepoint.com/sites/documentssite//_vti_bin/idcrl.svc```

### Some details about the issue
I noticed by running this script in debug mode, that the issue comes from the method ```acquire_authentication_cookie``` of the  class ```SamlTokenProvider```
Actually, the method is called with ```federated=True``` so the HTTP request is done at **https://mycompany.sharepoint.com/sites/documentssite//_vti_bin/idcrl.svc** with the HEAD method. You can find below the part where it fails :
```python
     def acquire_authentication_cookie(self, security_token, federated=False):
        ...
        else:
            self._auth_cookies['SPOIDCRL'] = None
            session.head(self.__sts_profile.signInPageUrl,
                         headers={
                             'User-Agent': 'Office365 Python Client',
                             'X-IDCRL_ACCEPTED': 't',
                             'Authorization': 'BPOSIDCRL {0}'.format(security_token),
                             'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'
                         })
        logger.debug_secrets("session.cookies: %s", session.cookies)
        cookies = requests.utils.dict_from_cookiejar(session.cookies)
        logger.debug_secrets("cookies: %s", cookies)
        if not cookies:
            self.error = "An error occurred while retrieving auth cookies from {0}".format(self.__sts_profile.signInPageUrl)
            logger.error(self.error)
            return False
```
The response does not contain any cookie, that's why I get the message error.

By the way, I got the same problem when I set url to 'https://mycompany.sharepoint.com'.

Let me know if I haven't given enough details about the issue.
Thank you in advance !

items.title: Big file upload does not work
items.body:
Hi Folks,

I have used the example provided to upload a big file. It creates the file in Sharepoint but the contents are not filled.

After some debugging, it seemed to me that the upload operation would start but would never be finished.

So I did the following changes to the code:
file `upload_session.py`
from:
``` python
for piece in read_in_chunks(fh, size=self._chunk_size):
    if f_pos == 0:
        upload_result = files.get_by_url(file_name).start_upload(self._upload_id, piece)
    elif f_pos + len(piece) < st.st_size:
        upload_result = files.get_by_url(file_name).continue_upload(self._upload_id, f_pos, piece)
    else:
        self._target_file = files.get_by_url(file_name).finish_upload(self._upload_id, f_pos, piece)
    f_pos += len(piece)
```

to 
``` python
for piece in read_in_chunks(fh, size=self._chunk_size): # when the bytes are over, the loop gets out, without calling the else in the previous code
    if f_pos == 0:
        upload_result = files.get_by_url(file_name).start_upload(self._upload_id, piece)
    elif f_pos + len(piece) < st.st_size:
        upload_result = files.get_by_url(file_name).continue_upload(self._upload_id, f_pos, piece)
    f_pos += len(piece)

# in my opinion this should always be called, as this is what tells sharepoint to close the file
self._target_file = files.get_by_url(file_name).finish_upload(self._upload_id, f_pos, piece)
```

items.title: sharepoint.client_context: Removing queries from a ClientContext
items.body:
Hello @vgrem et al.,

I found a cornercase using sharepoint's ClientContext. When I add there some queries via various methods of various classes and then call execute_query() and it raises an error, I cannot use that instance of ClientContext anymore. Because it is then not removed from the query queue. 

A workaround is to create a new ClientContext, but looks a bit unnatural to me.

Proposed ways how to fix it:  adding a method remove_queries, that will remove all queries from the context

What do you think about that?

an example code:
```python3
...

client_context = ClientContext(self._site_url, ctx_auth)
file: File = self.get_some_file()
try:
   file.checkout()
   client_context.execute_query()
except ClientRequestException:
   if ignore = True:
      logger.warning('ignoring checkout fail as instructed')
   else:
      raise
file.write(content=new_content)
file.checkin(comment='', checkin_type=1)   
file.execute_query()     # here checkout is called again
```

items.title: Folder rename - no change to folder or error
items.body:
Hello 👋 

I'm currently trying to rename a folder in a specific SharePoint site under the Shared Documents folder. My authenication and set up works (I am successfully creating Folders using a similar method) - however using the `.rename()` function from the `Folder` class is neither returning a renamed folder, or an error. My current code is below but I have tried many similar iterations:

```
def authenticate():
    ctx_auth = AuthenticationContext(SHAREPOINT_DOMAIN)
    if not ctx_auth.acquire_token_for_user(USERNAME, APP_PASS):
        raise Exception(
            "SharePoint Authentication failed, please ensure credentials are correct"
        )
    return ctx_auth

def update_folder_name(old_name, new_name):
    auth = authenticate()
    context = ClientContext(SHAREPOINT_SITE, auth)
    folder = context.web.get_folder_by_server_relative_url(f'Shared Documents/{old_name}')
    folder.rename(new_name)
    context.execute_query()

```


I am sure I am selecting the right folder with `folder = context.web.get_folder_by_server_relative_url(f'Shared Documents/{old_name}')` - if I print the contents of the folder then I get the expected output for example.

In `tests/test_sharepoint_folder.py`, the test to update a folder suggests to change the "Name" property but I do not think this is the right approach. Changing the "Title" and "FileLeafRef" as in the `rename` method is the right approach looking at the SharePoint REST API docs. 
Another thing to mention that using the logger, I can see my requests are POST, not the expected MERGE as mentioned in the docs (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/dev/sp-add-ins/working-with-folders-and-files-with-rest)

Any help would be greatly appreciated! Thanks!

items.title: Large files fail to upload to SharePoint
items.body:
I have a file that's over 500 MB that I need to upload to SharePoint. I'm hitting constraints using this library given an error message which states: `The server does not allow messages larger than 262144000 bytes`. Below is the full traceback.

I'm assuming this error is occurring because the file attempting to be uploaded is larger than the acceptable `chunksize` of 250MB for the REST API and Python client. 

I've been reviewing the codebase and documentation and am struggling to find a successful way to upload my file in chunks using your client library. Please don't take this as a slight; I'm happy to contribute on documentation if we can find resolution on this issue. My code snippet, which attempts the chunking process (3rd code snippet), is below.

My question for maintainers is two-fold:

1. Should end-users expect larger files not to be chunked via the Python Client (API wrapper). 

2. If yes to prior question, how would you recommend I leverage this library to upload large files to SharePoint. Below the traceback, you'll find my initial implementation (which should largely mimic the code found in the examples) which I've been using to perform uploads for smaller files.

**_**Traceback**_**
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ricky/.conda/envs/bi-export-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bi_exporter/models/base_operator.py", line 84, in execute
    self.returns = self.callable_object(*self.callable_args, **self.callable_kwargs)
  File "/home/ricky/.conda/envs/bi-export-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bi_exporter/core/sharepoint.py", line 18, in _upload_process
    context.execute_query()
  File "/home/ricky/.conda/envs/bi-export-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/office365/runtime/client_runtime_context.py", line 38, in execute_query
    self.pending_request.execute_query()
  File "/home/ricky/.conda/envs/bi-export-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/office365/runtime/client_request.py", line 32, in execute_query
    return self.execute_pending_queries()
  File "/home/ricky/.conda/envs/bi-export-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/office365/runtime/client_request.py", line 39, in execute_pending_queries
    self.process_payload_json(query, response)
  File "/home/ricky/.conda/envs/bi-export-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/office365/runtime/client_request.py", line 50, in process_payload_json
    self.validate_response(response)
  File "/home/ricky/.conda/envs/bi-export-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/office365/runtime/client_request.py", line 149, in validate_response
    raise ClientRequestException(*e.args, response=e.response)
office365.runtime.client_request_exception.ClientRequestException: ('-1, Microsoft.SharePoint.Client.InvalidClientQueryException', 'The request message is too big. The server does not allow messages larger than 262144000 bytes.', "400 Client Error: Bad Request for url: https://company.sharepoint.com/_api/Web/getfolderbyserverrelativeurl(directory_location)/Files/add(overwrite=true,url='report.csv')")
```

_**Initial implementation of function performing uploads to sharepoint**_
```
def _upload_process(local_path, ctx_client, sharepoint_directory):
    with open(local_path, 'rb') as file_to_upload:
        upload_content = file_to_upload.read()
    library = ctx_client.web.get_folder_by_server_relative_url(sharepoint_directory)
    context = library.context
    info = FileCreationInformation(url=os.path.basename(local_path), content=upload_content, overwrite=True)
    target_file = library.files.add(info)
    context.execute_query()
```

_**Chunking attempt**_
```
import os
import uuid

from office365.runtime.auth.authentication_context import AuthenticationContext
from office365.sharepoint.client_context import ClientContext
from office365.sharepoint.file import File


def sharepoint_auth(site, username, pw):
    ctx_auth = AuthenticationContext(url=site)
    if ctx_auth.acquire_token_for_user(username, pw):
        ctx_client = ClientContext(site, ctx_auth)
        return ctx_auth, ctx_client
    return ctx_auth


username = os.environ.get("SP_USER")
pw = os.environ.get("SP_PW")
site = os.environ.get("SP_PASS")
directory = os.environ.get("SP_PARENT_DIR")
upload_item = os.environ.get("SP_UPLOAD_ITEM")
desired_dest = os.environ.get("SP_CHILD_FOLDER")

upload_loc = os.path.join(directory, desired_dest)

auth, client = sharepoint_auth(site=site, username=username, pw=pw)
library = client.web.get_folder_by_server_relative_url(upload_loc)
context = library.context

chunksize = 50 * 1024  # 50 MB


chunks = list()
offset = 0
with open(upload_item, 'rb') as file_data:
    content = file_data.read()

total_size = len(content)

offsets = []
if total_size % chunksize != 0:
    offsets = [(x + 1) * chunksize for x in range(total_size // chunksize)] + [total_size]
else:
    offsets = [(x + 1) * chunksize for x in range(total_size // chunksize)]

sharepoint_file = File(context, os.path.basename(upload_item))
upload_id = uuid.uuid4()


for offset in offsets:
    if offsets.index(offset) == 0:
        sharepoint_file.start_upload(upload_id=upload_id, content=content)
    elif offsets.index(offset) == len(offsets):
        sharepoint_file.finish_upload(upload_id=upload_id, file_offset=offset, content=content)
    else:
        sharepoint_file.continue_upload(upload_id=upload_id, file_offset=offset, content=content)
```

Thank you in advance for your help and guidance. 

RS

items.title: Queries on sub sites yield wrong results
items.body:
This has been fixed in #111 before and got reintroduced again in the latest commits. The problem is the same as before. A `lists` query on a Sub `Web` object will yield the results of the Root Web. For example a site like this:

```plaintext
Root Web: [List 1, List 2, List 3]
└── Sub Web: [List 4, List 5]
```

The query `lists = sub_web.lists` will yield `[List 1, List 2, List 3]`, which is wrong.

Queries are created with URL from the context, which serves as a base URL. So basically the URL is created as follows: `query_url = context.url + "/_api/lists"`. Because the `context` never changes the `context.url` will be incorrect for queries on sub sites. Therefore I created a new context for every sub site in #111 to circumvent this issue. This got removed in the latest commits.

To print the sub sites recursively you added the parameter `parent_web_url` to `WebCollection` and it works on this type of collection:

https://github.com/vgrem/Office365-REST-Python-Client/blob/2a8b13c70c3294c597e7466570354ee66898c6a9/office365/sharepoint/web_collection.py#L7-L11

But all other types of collection do not have this kind of parameter and will therefore yield the wrong results. 

What do you think is the best approach for this? Creating a new context for sub sites or passing the parent web URL into the collections?

items.title: Towards continuous deployments to PyPI: deploy using Travis CI
items.body:
Ticket for myself.

**Status quo / Problem statement:** to release PyPI version, maintainer needs to execute commands from his own machine. This is "_suboptimal_", as Travis CI has built-in support for releasing code to PyPI.

**Improvement request:** modify `.travis.yml` to add deployment step. This should:

1. first stage: execute test matrix,
2. second stage: deploy **only if**
   * previous stage succeeded,
   * tag was created,
   * is executed from maintainer's fork (security considerations [[1](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/environment-variables/#encrypting-environment-variables)] [[2](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/encryption-keys)]).

This makes workflow much more pleasant: get tag from upsteam (this repo) and push to [maintainer's fork](https://github.com/kgadek/Office365-REST-Python-Client/).

items.title: Getting more than 100 items from a list
items.body:
I've been using examples/listitem_operations.py read_list_items() as a basis for a project I'm working on, and have hit a problem in that only the first 100 items in my list are returned.

[This](https://sharepoint.stackexchange.com/questions/74777/list-api-get-all-items-limited-to-100-rows) suggests that the underlying issue is that the underlying Sharepoint REST API is limited to returning 100 items at a time by default as a protection measure. There are some nasty hacks with $top= to increase the limit, but it appears the right way of retrieving an arbitrary number of items is to look for the existence of a link of the following form: 

```xml
<feed>
   ...
   <link rel="next" href=".../items?%24skiptoken=Paged%3dTRUE%26p_ID%3d100" />
</feed> 
```

on each set of results (the ... above is a contraction of the REST resource URI). This indicates that there are additional results, and provides a link to the next page.

Is accessing paged results possible with this client? Apologies if I'm missing something, but I can't find anything immediately obvious.
